ABOUT.TITLE: üçÖ What is the Pomodoro Technique?
ABOUT.SUBTITLE: Discover how this simple technique can revolutionize your productivity ‚Äî backed by scientific studies

WHAT_IS.TITLE: What is it?
WHAT_IS.P1: The Pomodoro Technique is a time management method based on clear work and break intervals. You focus for 25 minutes, take a 5-minute break, and start the next round. After four rounds, you take a longer break of 15 to 30 minutes.
WHAT_IS.P2: This way, your brain stays alert even during long work or study sessions ‚Äî whether reviewing notes, preparing for exams, or working on complex projects.

HISTORY.TITLE: üìú History
HISTORY.P1: The method was created in the late 1980s by Italian student Francesco Cirillo, using a tomato-shaped kitchen timer (hence the name: pomodoro = tomato in Italian).
HISTORY.P2: Frustrated with distractions and procrastination, Cirillo began dividing his study sessions into timed blocks. What started as a personal experiment became a globally recognized method, adopted by millions of people in various professional fields.

SCIENCE.TITLE: üî¨ What Does Science Say?
SCIENCE.INTRO: Evidence for the effectiveness of the Pomodoro technique is based on studies in cognitive neuroscience and behavioral psychology that analyze the impact of structured breaks on the brain.

BENEFITS.FATIGUE: 20% reduction in mental fatigue: Studies show that structured intervals result in less fatigue compared to self-directed breaks.
BENEFITS.PRODUCTIVITY: 25% increase in productivity: Professionals using the method report significant productivity gains, as the technique helps combat "attention burnout".
BENEFITS.GRADES: Up to 12% higher grades: Academic research indicates that students using the technique perform better on exams.
BENEFITS.BALANCE: Improved work-life balance: Individuals who adopted structured breaks reported a 15% increase in satisfaction with work-life balance.

SCIENCE.CONCLUSION: The technique aligns perfectly with our brain's natural rhythms, improving cognitive function and maximizing output.

STEPS.STEP1: Write down your goals: Define 1 to 3 tasks to accomplish
STEPS.STEP2: Set the timer: Set it for 25 minutes (1 pomodoro)
STEPS.STEP3: Work with total focus: Concentrate on a single task, without interruptions
STEPS.STEP4: Take a short break: Rest for 5 minutes ‚Äî stand up, drink water, rest your eyes
STEPS.STEP5: Repeat the cycle: Every 4 pomodoros, take a long break of 15-30 minutes

ITEMS.START: Makes starting easier: "Just 25 minutes" seems much less scary than "study for 3 hours" ‚Äî goodbye procrastination!
ITEMS.MOTIVATION: Keeps you motivated: Visible progress with each cycle keeps you engaged
ITEMS.STRUCTURE: Creates structure: Organizes your time without being overwhelming
ITEMS.BURNOUT: Prevents burnout: Regular breaks keep your mind fresh and rested
ITEMS.CREATIVITY: Improves creativity: Regular breaks enhance creativity and problem-solving skills
ITEMS.AWARENESS: Increases awareness: You become more aware of how you use your time and learn to better estimate task duration

AUDIENCE.TITLE: üë• Who Is It For?
AUDIENCE.INTRO: The Pomodoro Technique is ideal for:

ITEMS.STUDENTS: Students: Who need to stay focused during long study sessions and exam periods
ITEMS.DEVELOPERS: Developers: Who work with complex tasks requiring deep concentration
ITEMS.REMOTE: Remote workers: Who often deal with distractions at home
ITEMS.CREATIVES: Writers and Creatives: Who seek to keep creativity flowing without burning out
ITEMS.ADHD: People with ADHD: Studies show the technique significantly reduces stress by providing structure that replaces the difficult task of constant self-regulation
ITEMS.FREELANCERS: Freelancers: Who need to self-manage their time and productivity
ITEMS.ANYONE: Anyone: Who seeks to improve their focus, productivity, and well-being at work

MISTAKES.TITLE: ‚ö†Ô∏è Common Mistakes (and How to Avoid Them)

ITEMS.BIG_TASK: Task too big? Break it into smaller steps that fit in 1 to 4 Pomodoro cycles
ITEMS.MULTITASK: Multitasking? Switching between tabs and apps kills concentration ‚Äî focus on one task at a time
ITEMS.SOCIAL_MEDIA: Breaks = social media? Scrolling the feed is not rest! Move around, stretch, breathe, drink water ‚Äî away from screens
ITEMS.NO_REFLECTION: No reflection? Set aside 1 minute after each session to note what worked ‚Äî this improves the technique over time

ADVANCED.TITLE: üí° Advanced Tips
ADVANCED.INTRO: Combine the Pomodoro technique with smart learning strategies:

ITEMS.RECALL: Active recall: After each round, ask yourself 3 to 5 questions about what you learned
ITEMS.SPACED: Spaced repetition: Revisit the most difficult topics in several rounds over time
ITEMS.FLEXIBLE: Flexible intervals: Try 20-5 for beginners, 40-10 for deep work ‚Äî consistency matters more than exact numbers
ITEMS.DISTRACTIONS: Monitor distractions: Write down interruptions and correct triggers ‚Äî you'll notice significant improvement week after week

CTA.TITLE: üöÄ Ready to start?
CTA.P1: Now that you know the Pomodoro Technique and its scientifically proven benefits, why not try it? Use Pomode and discover how small focus blocks can generate big results!
CTA.P2: Start today with just three rounds ‚Äî observe where you get distracted and adjust the intervals. You'll quickly find the ideal rhythm for your brain.
